subject: Re: [junit] Future of testing tools
msgSnippet: ... In my experience the this dependency tends to become a parameter to the static method which makes the method a little more complex. Furthermore: all
messageBody:
> Yet, static methods have one less dependency than instance methods
> (they don't depend on 'this' to run correctly), which is why static
> methods are usually easier to move around than instance ones.

In my experience the "this" dependency tends to become a parameter to
the static method which makes the method a little more complex.
Furthermore: all classes that use the static method need to satisfy
the dependency that in the case of an "instance one" could be
satisfied by the constructor when the instance is created.

Of course this is generally speaking and probably subjective but I
think saying that static methods have one less dependency is
simplifying things somewhat.

Of course YMMV
/J
